_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: State of Illinois, Fertilizer Law, Subpart A, Anhydrous Ammonia
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, piping, pump, and nurse tanks

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility:  Circle R Fertilize, Inc.
                   2198 U.S. Highway 45
                   Springerton, Il 62887
    Contact:  Danny E. Rose
    Phone:    618-963-2205

    1.    Facility Policy
    
           The owners,  Management and employees of Circle R Fertilize, Inc. Are committed to the prevent-
           ion of any accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. If any accidental releases should occur,
           the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, White county LEPC, and/or other 
           authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.

   2.    Facility Information.
   
          The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous
   ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.      
   The maximum quantity stored would be 260,000 pounds in the storage tank and nurse tanks.
   
   3.    Worst-Case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario.

          A.  The worst-case scenario would be the release of the total contents of our storage tank 
    released as gas over a period of 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be 130,000 
    pounds, which representsthe volume of the storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design 
    standards and administrative controls. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 parts
    per million, or ppm) is 1.12 miles.

          B.   The alternate release scenario, a 3 inch pipe is used as an alternate release scenario followed
    by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic excess flow shut-down valve/valves
    intervennes, or a valve is closed manually downstream of the leak, and stops the flow of ammonia.
    The maximum quantity released wold be 26,638 pounds. The endpoint(point of dispersion to 200
    parts per million) is .78 mile.

  4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program.

This facility is in compliance with the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA),
    29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia, and the State of Illinois Fertilizer Law.
    The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form, see Section 8.3 (b).

   5.    Five-Year Accident History.
  
         There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have 
    caused any deaths, injuries or significant damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has there
    been any accidental releases resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage,
    or environmental damage.

   6.    Emergency Action Plan.

          This Facility has:

          a.   A written action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38;
         
          b.   Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know
                information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

          c.   If a large release of Anhydrous Ammonia should happenat this facility, the required response
                action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response
                numbers.
                1.    Within 15 minutes of determining the amount of the release would be over 100 pounds,
                       the Emergency Coordinator will notify:

                              The National Emergency Response Center @ 800/424-8802
                
                2.    Immediately (within one hour) after determining that the amount of release would be
                       over 100 pounds, The Emergency Coordinator will notify:

                        The Illinois Environmental Management Agency @ 800-782-7860 (in state) or 
                         217-782-7860 (out of state).
      

    7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

                Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility

. Periodic evaluations are performed
                to access the conditions of the facility. There are NO additional specific safety 
                recommendations regarding storage or use of Anhydrous Ammonia for implementation at
                this time.
